about.title:
Hi! My name is Khaled,
I'm a Product Designer (UX/UI) & Frontend Developer based in Germany
about.description: Product Designer & Frontend Developer with a Computer Science background, C1 German level, and 5+ years of experience designing and developing digital products across education, e-commerce, fintech, and language-learning. Skilled in leading UX/UI processes, building design systems, and implementing modern frontends (React, TypeScript, Flutter). Strong technical understanding demonstrated through ICPC World Finals participation as a coach and formal UX Weiterbildung in Germany.

portfolio.intro:
Buber was the first mobile ride-hailing platform designed specifically for the social and cultural context of Afghanistan. Many people in Afghanistan are cautious when it comes to adopting new technology, so the product needed to be exceptionally clear, trustworthy, and easy to use. My focus in the design process was on:
Very simple interaction flows (minimal steps & clear icons).
Strong sense of safety and transparency (driver identity, route preview, upfront pricing).
This approach made Buber accessible to a wide range of users, including those who had little or no previous experience with smartphone apps. The platform helped build confidence in digital services and contributed to the early growth of app-based mobility in Afghanistan.

section.visualLead: Mini-apps for everyday use — such as payments, restaurant ordering and company service tools — designed for simplicity, accessibility and fast, intuitive interaction.

whatIs.description: UI/UX design stands for User Interface/User Experience design. It involves creating visually appealing and user-friendly interfaces for digital products. UI design focuses on the product's look and feel, including colors, typography, and layouts. UX design enhances the overall user experience, considering factors like usability, accessibility, and interaction design. UI and UX design work together to create intuitive and enjoyable experiences for users.

uxAudits.title: UX Audits
uxAudits.paragraph1: A UX audit is a service that evaluates the user experience (UX) of a website. It involves analyzing the website's design, functionality, and content to identify areas of improvement that can enhance the user's overall experience.
uxAudits.paragraph2: During a UX audit, a team of UX experts will conduct a thorough review of the website and provide a comprehensive report that outlines specific recommendations for improving the website's usability, accessibility, and overall user experience.
uxAudits.paragraph3: The audit may cover various aspects of the website, such as navigation, layout, visual design, content structure, and mobile responsiveness. The goal is to identify any pain points or obstacles that users may encounter while browsing the website and provide actionable recommendations to improve their experience.
uxAudits.paragraph4: In summary, a UX audit can help website owners identify areas of improvement that can enhance their website's user experience and increase user engagement and satisfaction.

designThinking.title: Design thinking
designThinking.paragraph1: Design thinking is a problem-solving approach that emphasizes empathy, creativity, and collaboration. It involves understanding the needs and perspectives of users, identifying and defining the problem, generating multiple possible solutions, prototyping and testing those solutions, and iterating based on feedback.
designThinking.paragraph2: Design thinking encourages a human-centered approach to innovation and is often used in fields such as product design, user experience (UX) design, and business strategy to create user-centric and innovative solutions. It promotes a mindset that embraces experimentation, iteration, and continuous learning throughout the design process.

wireframing.title: wireframing
wireframing.paragraph1: Wireframing is a vital step in web design where a visual representation of a website's structure is created. It focuses on layout and user experience, using basic shapes and lines to outline elements like headers, menus, and content sections. Wireframes establish the website's architecture and functionality, facilitating communication between designers, developers, and clients. They serve as a blueprint for user-friendly websites, setting the foundation for design and development.

brandDiscovery.title: 1- Brand Discovery
brandDiscovery.body:
Brand Discovery is the phase where we learn about your business, your users, and your goals. We identify what makes your brand unique and define the direction for the entire project.
Output: Brand Brief (1–2 pages)
Time: 7 days out of 100 days (Project X)

brandIdentity.title: 2- Brand Identity
brandIdentity.body:
Brand Identity defines the personality and voice of your brand. We decide how the brand should feel — friendly, professional, playful, or elegant — so that communication stays consistent everywhere.
Output: Brand Personality + Tone of Voice (1–2 pages)
Time: 6 days out of 100 days (Project X)

logoDesign.title: 3- Logo Design
logoDesign.body:
Logo Design is where we create the visual symbol of your brand. We start with sketching multiple concepts, refine the strongest one, and finalize it in different formats for all use cases.
Output: Final Logo + Variations (Color, Black/White, Icon)
Time: 8 days out of 100 days (Project X)

brandGuidelines.title: 4- Brand Guidelines
brandGuidelines.body:
Brand Guidelines define how your brand should look and be used. This includes colors, fonts, logo rules, icons, image style, and spacing. It ensures your brand always appears consistent — no matter who designs what.
Output: Brand Book (PDF with rules & visual standards)
Time: 9 days out of 100 days (Project X)

informationArchitecture.title: 5- Information Architecture
informationArchitecture.body:
Information Architecture defines how content and pages are organized. We plan the sitemap and user flows so users can easily find what they need without confusion.
Output: Sitemap + User Flow Diagram
Time: 5 days out of 100 days (Project X)

contentStrategy.title: 6- Content Strategy
contentStrategy.body:
Content Strategy defines what each page should say and how it should communicate. We clarify the main message, key headlines, and structure of text — so users understand the product clearly and quickly.
Output: Page Messaging + Core Copy Direction (1–2 pages per main section)
Time: 5 days out of 100 days (Project X)

wireframes.title: 7- Wireframes
wireframes.body:
Wireframes are simple, black-and-white layouts that show the structure of each screen without colors or visual styling. This step helps us confirm layout, placement, and flow before spending time on detailed design.
Output: Low-Fidelity Wireframes for all key pages
Time: 10 days out of 100 days (Project X)

uiDesign.title: 8- UI Design
uiDesign.body:
UI Design is where we create the final visual look of the product. We apply colors, typography, spacing, icons, components, and the brand style to each page. This step makes the product visually clear, modern, and consistent.
Output: High-Fidelity UI Designs for all main screens + UI Style Components
Time: 20 days out of 100 days (Project X)

prototype.title: 9- Prototype
prototype.body:
The prototype is an interactive, clickable version of the design. It allows you and real users to experience the flow of the product before development begins.
Output: Clickable Figma Prototype
Time: 7 days out of 100 days (Project X)

usabilityTesting.title: 10- Usability Testing
usabilityTesting.body:
Usability Testing checks how real users interact with the prototype. We observe where they struggle and make improvements to ensure the experience is clear and easy to use.
Output: Test Report + List of Improvements
Time: 6 days out of 100 days (Project X)

designSystem.title: 11- Design System & UI Kit
designSystem.body:
The Design System & UI Kit is a library of reusable visual components (buttons, inputs, icons, spacing rules, etc.). It ensures consistency and allows developers to work faster and with fewer errors.
Output: UI Component Library + Design Rules Document
Time: 8 days out of 100 days (Project X)

developerHandoff.title: 12- Developer Handoff
developerHandoff.body:
Developer handoff is where we prepare and organize all design files so the development team can build the product correctly. We provide assets, specifications, component behaviors, and clear instructions to avoid misunderstandings.
Output: Organized Figma Files + Exported Assets + Implementation Notes
Time: 5 days out of 100 days (Project X)

postLaunch.title: 13- Post-Launch Optimization
postLaunch.body:
Post-launch optimization happens after the product goes live. We review real user behavior, identify any usability issues, and make small improvements to enhance the experience.
Output: Analytics Report + List of UX Improvements + Updated Screens (if needed)
Time: 4 days out of 100 days (Project X)
